novels.title: Antkind
novels.author: Charlie Kaufman
novels.comment: Self-deprecating absurdism that can be extremely compelling, even if a little too slapstick for its own good.

novels.title: The Man in the High Castle
novels.author: Philip K Dick

novels.title: The Sailor Who Fell from Grace with the Sea
novels.author: Yukio Mishima
novels.comment: Expertly paced, the characters only remain familiar long enough for the reader to grow complacent, then the interesting depths of their natures arise.

novels.title: Termination Shock
novels.author: Neal Stephenson
novels.comment:
Less grandiose than many of his outings, more focused along a very likely, very near future, this book attempts to deal with the oncoming devastation of climate change.
Like Reamde, it becomes an action book a little too early, solving so much with combat that it replaces a valuable, nuanced discussion with overt violence.

novels.title: Bleeding Edge
novels.author: Thomas Pynchon
novels.comment: Love his modern look back at the dying days of the dotcom bubble and the chaos of living in New York City in 2001.

novels.title: Breasts and Eggs
novels.author: Mieko Kawakami
novels.comment: A dynamite book in two parts, both dealing with the strangeness of being a woman in a modern city.

novels.title: Neuromancer
novels.author: William Gibson
novels.comment: Best of the Best.  This novel created a genre for a reason, even though other examples of the genre's elements already existed.  Impeccable style and expert prose throughout.

novels.title: Severance
novels.author: Ling Ma
novels.comment: Amazing look at how workplace dynamics can threaten to overshadow one's real place in the world.

novels.title: The Great Offshore Grounds
novels.author: Vanessa Veselka
novels.comment: For a moment in the middle, the book seemed to meander and lose itself, but everything eventually found its footing. The complexity of the characters and the clashes of their personalities glows as their mettle is continuously challenged.
